newsitem.title: UK: Euro straight-run fuel steady after $109 cargo deal.
newsitem.headline: Euro straight-run fuel steady after $109 cargo deal.

text.p: European low sulphur fuel oil was steady on Friday after a cargo deal confirmed current values, while Russian material was in short supply and commanding good premiums, traders said.

A 27,000 tonne cargo of Scandinavian straight-run sold into Britain for $109 a tonne fob, a number lower than the seller originally wanted but generally agreed to be as high as the market would support.
The next European cargo on offer was not due to load until June 5-10, traders said.
While the summer flow of Russian fuel oil has begun in earnest most of it has been cracked material instead of the anticipated straight-run.

Consequently high sulphur straight-run has been perceived as rare. E-4s were believed to be changing hands at three means plus $4-$5, with the going rate for M-100s two means plus $6-$7 and for M40s three means flat.
